titles.title: How to keep your sanity when preparing a transcript of an online interview for publication
Form, pattern & texture in the typographic image

citation.unstructured_citation: Tim Ahrens and Shoko Mugikura, Size Specific Adjustments to Type Designs. Garching, Germany: Just Another Foundry, 2013.
Nicolas Barker, “The Aldine Roman in Paris, 1530–1534”. The Library, v.s5-XXIX, n.1, Mar. 1974, pp.5–20. https://doi.org/10.1093/library/s5-XXIX.1.5

Charles Bigelow, “On Type: Optical letter spacing for new printing systems”. Fine Print, vol.4, no.3, Oct. 1977. Reprinted in Visible Language, vol.11, no.3, 1977, pp.325–329, https://visiblelanguage.herokuapp.com/issue/43
Charles Bigelow and Donald Day, “Digital typography”. Scientific American, vol.249, no.2, Aug. 1983, pp.106–119.
Charles Bigelow, Kris Holmes, “The design of Lucida”, in Text Processing and Document Manipulation, J.C. van Vliet, ed. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1986, pp.1–17.
Charles Bigelow, Kris Holmes, “Science and history behind the design of Lucida”. TUGboat, v.39, n.3, pp.204–211, 2018. https://tug.org/TUGboat/tb39-3/tb123bigelow-lucida.pdf
Charles Bigelow, “Typeface features and legibility research”. Vision Research, v.165, Dec. 2019, pp.162–172.

Harry Carter, “The optical scale in typefounding”, in Typography 4, pp.144–148. London: The Shenval Press, 1937. Reprinted as “Optical scale in type founding”, The Printing Historical Society Bulletin, v.13, 1984, pp.144–148. London: St Bride Institute. https://issuu.com/letterror/docs/harry_carter_optical_scale_in_typefounding
Franz Boas and Charles Cultee (narrator), Chinook Texts. Washington: Smithsonian Institution, Bureau of Ethnology, 1894.
Harry Carter, ed., Sixteenth Century French Type-founders: The Le Bé Memorandum. Paris: André Jammes, 1967.
Susana T.L. Chung, “The Effect of Letter Spacing on Reading Speed in Central and Peripheral Vision”. Investigative Ophthalmology & Visual Science, v.43, n.4, 2002, pp.1270–1276.
Persi Diaconis and David Freedman, “On the Statistics of Vision: The Julesz Conjecture”. Journal of Mathematical Psychology, vol.24, no.2, 1981.

John Dreyfus, ed., “Specimen no. 2: Konrad Berner, Frankfurt 1592”, in Type Specimen Facsimiles. John Dreyfus, general editor, with research by A.F. Johnson, Harry Carter, Matthew Carter, Netty Hoeflake, Mike Parker. London: Bowes & Bowes, 1963.
John Dreyfus, French Eighteenth Century Typography. Cambridge, U.K.: The Roxburghe Club, 1982.

Pierre Simon Fournier, Manuel Typographique. Paris: Fournier (and Barbou), 1764–66; Harry Carter, trans. Fournier on Typefounding. New York: Burt Franklin, 1973. First edition: Pierre Simon Fournier, Harry Carter, Fournier on Typefounding. The Text of the Manuel Typographique, 1764–1766. Translated and edited with notes by Harry Carter. [With a Portrait.] London: Soncino Press, 1930.

Arthur P. Ginsburg, “Visual information processing based on spatial filters constrained by biological data”. Report no.AMRL-TR-78-129-VOL-1/2, Air Force Aerospace Medical Research Lab, Wright-Patterson AFB, Ohio, USA, 1978.
Eric Gill, An Essay on Typography. London: Sheed & Ward, 1936. Reprinted, Boston: David R. Godine, 1988.
Chauncey Griffith, quoted by Edmund C. Arnold in Functional Newspaper Design. New York: Harper & Brothers, 1956.
Branko Grünbaum and G.C. Shephard, Tilings and Patterns. New York: W.H. Freeman, 1986.
David H. Hubel, Eye, Brain, and Vision. New York: Scientific American Library, 1988.

Dell Hymes, “Victoria Howard’s ‘Gitskux and his Older Brother’: A Clackamas Chinook Myth”, in Smoothing the Ground: Essays on Native American Oral Literature. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press, 1983.
Melville Jacobs and Victoria Howard (narrator), Clackamas-Chinook Texts. Bloomington: Indiana University Research Center in Anthropology, Folklore, and Linguistics, 1958.
Bela Julesz, “Texture and Visual Perception”. Scientific American, vol.212, no.2, Feb. 1965, pp.38–48.
“Experiments in the Visual Perception of Texture”. Scientific American, vol.232, no.4, Apr. 1975, pp.34–43.
Kevin Larson, “The Science of Word Recognition”. Lecture at Association Typographique Internationale, Sept. 2003. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/typography/develop/word-recognition

Kevin Larson, Matthew Carter, “Sitka: A collaboration between type design and science”, in Digital Fonts and Reading, Mary C. Dyson, Ching Yee Suen, eds., pp.37–53. Singapore: World Scientific, 2016. https://microsoft.com/en-us/research/publication/sitka-a-collaboration-between-type-design-and-science/
Gordon E. Legge, Psychophysics of Reading in Normal and Low Vision. Mahwah, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, 2007, pp.60–65.

Gordon E. Legge, Charles A. Bigelow, “Does print size matter for reading? A review of findings from vision science and typography”. Journal of Vision, v.11, n.5, Aug. 2011. https://doi.org/10.1167/11.5.8

El (Lazar Markovich) Lissitzky, “Our Book”, in Gutenberg Jahrbuch 1926 7. Mainz: Gutenberg-Gesellschaft. English translation by Helene Aldwinkel, in El Lissitzky, Sophie Lissitzky-Küppers, ed. London: Thames and Hudson, 1980.
Najib J. Majaj, Denis G. Pelli, Peri Kurshan, Melanie Palomares, “The role of spatial frequency channels in letter identification”. Vision Research, vol.42, no.9, Apr. 2002, pp.1165–1184.
Andre Malraux, “Museum Without Walls”, in The Voices of Silence. Stuart Gilbert, trans. Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1978.

Andre Martinet, Éléments de Linguistique Generale. Paris: Librairie Armand Colin, 1967. Martinet follows an observation made by Ferdinand de Saussure in Cours de linguistique generale, Charles Bally and Albert Sechehaye eds., 1916. English edition: Course in General Linguistics, Wade Baskin, trans. New York: The Philosophical Library, 1959.
Andre Martinet, “The Word”. Diogenes 51, 1965.
Hans Ed. Meier, personal communication.
Robert Morris, “Spectral font signatures”. Technical Report of the Department of Mathematics and Computer Science. Boston: University of Massachusetts, 1989.
Robert Morris, “Image processing aspects of type”, in Document Manipulation and Typography, J.C. van Vliet, ed. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1988.
Blaise Pascal, Serie XXII, 512, in Pensées. Paris: Editions du Seuil, 1962.
Denis G. Pelli, Bart Farell, Deborah C. Moore, “The remarkable inefficiency of word recognition”. Letter to Nature, Nature, vol.423, no.6941, June 12, 2003, pp.752–756.
Denis G. Pelli, Katherine A. Tillman, “The uncrowded window of object recognition”. Nature Neuroscience, v.11, n.10, Oct. 2008, pp.1129–1135.
John R. Pierce, An Introduction to Information Theory: Symbols, Signals and Noise. New York: Dover Publications, 1980.
John R. Pierce, The Science of Musical Sound. New York: Scientific American Library, 1983.
Floyd Ratliff, “Contour and Contrast”. Scientific American, vol.226, no.6, June 1972, pp.9–20.
Erich Schulz-Anker, “Syntax-Antiqua, a Sans Serif on a New Basis”. Gebrauchsgraphik n.8, 1970, pp.49–56.
A.V. Shubnikov and V.A. Koptsik, Symmetry in Science and Art. G.D. Archard, trans. New York: Plenum Press, 1974.
Walter Tracy, Letters of Credit. Boston: David R. Godine, 1986.
Jan Tschichold, A Treasury of Alphabets and Lettering. New York: Reinhold, 1966.

Jan Tschichold, “Ton in des Töpfers Hand”, in Ausgewählte Aufsätze uber Fragen der Gestalt des Buches und der Typographie. Basel: Birkhäuser, 1975. English translation by Hajo Hadler, as “Clay in a Potter’s Hand”, in The Form of the Book, Robert Bringhurst, ed. Vancouver, Canada: Hartley & Marks Publishers, 1991. (Hadler’s translation differs somewhat from the one in this essay.)
Daniel Berkeley Updike, Printing Types: Their History, Forms, and Use, A Study in Survivals. Cambridge, Massachusetts: Harvard University Press, 1937.

H.D.L. Vervliet, Harry Carter, eds., “Specimen no. 17: Plantin’s Folio Specimen c.1585” and “Specimen no. 18: The Le Bé–Moretus Collection of Fragments c.1599” in Type Specimen Facsimiles II. Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 1972.

Hendrik D.L. Vervliet, French Renaissance Printing Types: A Conspectus. New Castle, DE, USA: Oak Knoll Press, 2010. Simultaneously published in London by the Bibliographical Society and the Printing Historical Society, p.36.

Beatrice Warde, “The Crystal Goblet, or Printing Should be Invisible”, originally an address entitled “Printing Should be Invisible”, given to the British Typographers’ Guild at the St Bride Institute, London, 1932. Reprinted in The Crystal Goblet: Sixteen Essays on Typography. London: Sylvan Press, 1955; Cleveland and New York: The World Publishing Co., 1956. Also reprinted in The Monotype Recorder, vol.44, no.1, Autumn 1970. https://readings.design/PDF/The%20Crystal%20Goblet.pdf
Hermann Weyl, Symmetry. Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1952.
